problem_text:
Angular Diameter and Width of Plane Convex Bodies

PROBLEM:
Study the class of plane convex bodies C in terms of the θ-diameter Dθ(C) and the θ-width Wθ(C). In particular, determine the greatest lower bound of the quotient Dπ/2/D0.

When C is a plane convex body and 0 ≤ θ < π, the θ-diameter Dθ(C) (resp. the θ-width Wθ(C)) is defined as the length of the longest (resp. the shortest) chord of C which joins two rays of support enclosing an angle of θ. Thus D0 and W0 are the ordinary diameter and width, and C is of constant width if and only if D0(C) = W0(C). It would be interesting to study the sets of constant θ-width – those for which Dθ = Wθ.

In [1,3], J. W. Green has established some relationships among the functions Dπ/2, Wπ/2, D0, and W0, showing that

Dπ/2 / D0 > (√7 − 1) / 3,
Dπ/2 / W0 ≥ 1/√2,
Wπ/2 / D0 ≤ 1/√2,
and Wπ/2 / W0 < 1,

with equality in either case only for the circular disc. He shows further that each of the last three bounds is the best possible, but that the first is not. He conjectures in [3] that Dπ/2/D0 ≥ 1/2, but has informed us recently that a counterexample has been found by R. H. Sorgenfrey. It remains, then, to determine the greatest lower bound of the quotient Dπ/2/D0.
